Articles.Content:
I've late lately been considering the role of water in the game, and Infinite dice's Boat Parts mod is possibly the best put together pack here (or will be once he patches it for 0.21)

Thus, I've been considering how difficult would it be to implement a Mun influenced tide? Aside from the difficulties of varying the sea level right across the globe, how would it effect floating vessels? Could it be exploited to generate power and launch large ships?
are you trying to kill or computers? You know, te oceans right now, are the principal cause of lag when you are on a planet. They are loaded as planets, indeed.
No... Just no... would be too laggy just for eye candy...
Consensus appears to be far too much work and CPU strain for too little real benefit. It'll be interesting to see where we are in a few years when Squad get round to sorting the oceans.
My game would crash upon double clicking the exe.
I think you people may be overestimating the strain this would put on CPU's. Not much more than weather I'd think.
What about implementing it for tidally locked moons, at least? Their tides are static, with a bulge towards the parent body. At the moment, this would only apply to Laythe.
In fact this would NOT require much cpu resources.
Tides would require too much effort on the devs part when they should be focusing on other promised game features.

Isn't the ocean just a sphere overlaying the shape of the surface terrain proper? I assume changing it shape by adding bulges that rotate at the same rate as the Mun wouldn't be too difficult. The question is though why bother? It doesn't add anything to gameplay really, not until actual boat functionality gets added (which I assume is a very low priority). I rather see wind and other weather which would affect flight rather than something which is quite frankly pointless.
I don't think it would really add anything. I don't think most SHIP simulators have this.
seems you could do this by just tweaking a transform matrix that you would need to pass every poly through anyway.

seems you could do this by just tweaking a transform matrix that you would need to pass every poly through anyway.

I don't quite think that's how the translate matrix works.

transform matrix != translation matrix. theres a difference. a transform matrix is just a matrix that lets you transform a vector. it can be a rotation or a translation, etc, or a bunch of transformations rolled into one matrix, but the specific transformation you want for this is scale.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transform_matrix
